block.p: DIGITAL MOVIES AT WALMART.COM -- Wal-Mart, the country's largest seller of movies on DVD, said it would begin testing a video download service next year over its Web site, walmart.com. [Page C1.]

PFIZER TO CUT SALES FORCE -- Pfizer said that it would lay off almost 2,400 sales representatives and managers, which is a fifth of its American sales force but only 2 percent of its worldwide work force. The move may indicate the beginning of a wider retrenchment by Pfizer and the rest of the drug industry. [C1.]

TOYOTA'S CHIEF STEPS OUT -- Katsuaki Watanabe, named last year to lead Toyota in what many assumed would be a caretaker role until the great-grandson of the company's founder was to take charge, has been raising his profile, stepping out as the leader of a company that may soon displace General Motors as the world's biggest automaker. [C1.]

CHARGES OF BRIBERY IN CHINA DEAL -- A federal lawsuit contends that Fidelity Information Services, an American software company, bribed two Chinese banking officials and family members with vacations to Hong Kong, Paris, Rome, Las Vegas and the golfing resort of Pebble Beach, Calif. The company says the trips were a legitimate cost of doing business in China. [C1.]

REGULATORY GROUPS TO MERGE -- The New York Stock Exchange and NASD announced plans to merge their regulatory organizations and eliminate duplicative and inconsistent rules, granting Wall Street firms a longstanding wish. [C1.]

A MERGER'S UNUSUAL PROVISION -- A proposed merger of the regulatory operations of NASD and those of the New York Stock Exchange includes an unusual provision that would pay every one of the 5,100 NASD members $35,000 if the merger is approved. The merger cannot be completed unless a majority of those firms vote for it. Market Place. [C6.]

BLACKS HELD BACK AT LAW FIRMS -- Thanks to vigorous recruiting and pressure from corporate clients, black lawyers are well represented now among new associates at the nation's most prestigious law firms. But they remain far less likely to stay at the firms or to make partner than their white counterparts, according to a study. [A1.]

GLOBAL WARMING ON TRIAL -- The Supreme Court will hear oral arguments on the questions of whether the federal government, particularly the Environmental Protection Agency, is authorized and obligated to take action to alleviate global warming. [A22.]

DISCRIMINATION AND THE DOLLAR -- A federal judge ruled that the government illegally discriminated against blind people by printing all of its paper currency on bills of the same size that cannot be distinguished by touch. [A22.]

FED WARNING ON INFLATION -- Signaling that the Fed is not inclined to lower interest rates any time soon, its chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said that while economic growth should rebound next year, inflation remained ''uncomfortably high.'' [C3.]
EUROPEAN POWER DEAL -- The Spanish power company Iberdrola announced that it had agreed to buy ScottishPower for $22.5 billion, a move that would create one of Europe's largest utilities. [C3.]

AN 'OBVIOUS' PATENT CASE -- To be eligible for a patent, an invention must not be ''obvious'' to a person of ''ordinary skill'' in the field, according to statute. While the meaning of the term ''obvious'' might appear to be obvious, a lively and surprisingly entertaining Supreme Court argument demonstrated that it is not. [C3.]

RUSSIAN ENERGY PACT -- The chief executives of Rosneft and Gazprom signed a cooperation agreement, mending a rift between the two Russian state energy companies that had been slowing investment in the development of new fields. [C5.]

PARSONS AND POLITICS -- Richard D. Parsons, the chief executive of Time Warner, is often mentioned as a possible candidate to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The thought came up again yesterday during a question-and-answer session at a media conference. [B2.]

MARKETS STAND FIRM -- Stocks advanced modestly after Wall Street shrugged off a sharp drop in orders for manufactured goods and took comfort in the first gain in existing-home sales in eight months. [C11.]

ServiceMaster, the lawn care and pest control company, said yesterday that it was considering putting itself up for sale, sending shares up more than 10 percent. The company, which has a market value of about $3.5 billion, said it was exploring strategic alternatives and had hired Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs as financial advisers and Sidley Austin as legal adviser. The company has faced higher costs while struggling to retain customers. (REUTERS)

Nokia, the world's top cellphone maker, cut its profit margin forecast but remained more upbeat than analysts as it introduced thinner models that will face stiff competition and slower market growth. Nokia cut its target for its group operating profit margin for the next one to two years to 15 percent from an earlier 17 percent. (REUTERS)

ITV, the struggling British broadcaster, raided the top ranks of the BBC on Tuesday and lured away its chairman. Michael Grade, 63, who joined the British Broadcasting Corporation in 2004 on a four-year contract, is defecting to ITV, the country's largest commercial broadcaster. A week ago, ITV spurned a takeover offer from NTL. (IHT)
